me.wobblyyyy.pathfinder2.execution

Class ExecutorManager

  • java.lang.Object
    • me.wobblyyyy.pathfinder2.execution.ExecutorManager

  • public class ExecutorManager
extends java.lang.Object
    A manager, responsible for... well, managing executors. This manager operates on a first-in, first-out basis. Basically, you can add a follower executor to the queue of executors. The manager will continue executing the executor that was added first until it's finished, and then it'll move onto the next executor.

    There are only two ways you can interact with the queue of executors here.

    • Add an executor by adding a list of followers.
    • Clear the entire list of executors.

    Executor managers are a relatively simple and limited method of managing autonomous movement - this is completely intentional, as to not overcomplicate usage of the library.

    Since:
    0.0.0
    Author:
    Colin Robertson
    See Also:
    FollowerExecutor

    • Constructor Detail

      • ExecutorManager

        public ExecutorManager(Robot robot)
        Create a new ExecutorManager. By default, new managers will not have any executors.
        Parameters:
        robot - the robot.

    • Method Detail

      • addExecutor

        public void addExecutor(java.util.List<Follower> followers)
        Add an executor to the manager. Because this manager operates on a first-in, first-out model, the follower list you've added will be executed after any other executors have finished.
        Parameters:
        followers - a list of followers. These followers will be used to create a new FollowerExecutor.

      • addExecutor

        public void addExecutor(Follower follower)
        Add an executor to the manager. Because this manager operates on a first-in, first-out model, the follower you've added will be executed after any other executors have finished.
        Parameters:
        follower - a single follower to add.

      • clearExecutors

        public void clearExecutors()
        Clear the list of FollowerExecutors.

        This will, in effect, stop the robot. Because there's no longer any followers to execute, Pathfinder will do... just about nothing. It's still important that you actually tick Pathfinder after clearing the executors - this will stop the robot from moving.

      • isActive

        public boolean isActive()
        Is the executor manager active?
        Returns:
        true if the executor manager has at least 1 executor in queue. False if not.

      • isInactive

        public boolean isInactive()
        The opposite of the isActive() method.
        Returns:
        the opposite of the isActive() method.

      • tick

        public boolean tick()
        Tick the ExecutorManager once. The tick method returns a boolean value indicating the status of the ExecutorManager. If the method returns true, the ExecutorManager has finished its execution - this means all the FollowerExecutors have finished their execution. If the method returns false, the ExecutorManager hasn't yet finished its execution.
        Returns:
        true if there are no remaining executors in the list. False if there are still remaining executors.

      • howManyExecutors

        public int howManyExecutors()
        Get a count of how many executors there are.
        Returns:
        how many executors there are.

      • howManyFollowers

        public int howManyFollowers()

      • getExecutionTime

        public double getExecutionTime()
        Get how long the current follower has been executing. If no followers have executed, this will return 0. If no followers are active, but a follower has been active in the past, this will return the execution time of the last follower.
        Returns:
        the execution time of the current follower.

      • getCurrentExecutor

        public FollowerExecutor getCurrentExecutor()
